questions.question: What is the proportion of the Earth’s surface covered by water?
questions.answer: Around 71% of the Earth’s surface is covered by water.

questions.question: What is the ocean floor?
questions.answer: The ocean floor is the land submerged below oceanic water.

questions.question: What is the average depth of the oceans?
questions.answer: The average depth of the oceans is around 3700 metres.

questions.question: What is a continental shelf?
questions.answer: The continental shelf is the shallowest part of the ocean bed, near the coast and submerged under the sea.

questions.question: What is the depth range of the continental shelf?
questions.answer: The continental shelf extends up to 200 metres below sea level.

questions.question: Why is the continental shelf important for fishing?
questions.answer: Sunlight reaches its bed, allowing algae and plankton to grow, which serve as food for fish.

questions.question: Give an example of an oil-rich area on a continental shelf.
questions.answer: Mumbai High on the continental shelf of the Arabian Sea is rich in mineral oil and natural gas.

questions.question: What is the continental slope?
questions.answer: The continental slope is the steep slope that begins after the continental shelf ends.

questions.question: What is the depth range of the continental slope?
questions.answer: The continental slope ranges from 200 metres to 3600 metres below sea level.

questions.question: What lies beyond the continental slope?
questions.answer: Abyssal plains lie beyond the continental slope.

questions.question: What are abyssal plains?
questions.answer: Abyssal plains are the flat parts of the sea bed beyond the continental slope.

questions.question: What are submerged hills and mountains?
questions.answer: Submerged hills and mountains are landforms found on the ocean bed, sometimes rising above sea level as islands.

questions.question: Give an example of marine islands formed by submerged mountains.
questions.answer: The Andaman and Nicobar Islands in the Bay of Bengal are peaks of submerged mountains.

questions.question: What are oceanic plateaus?
questions.answer: Oceanic plateaus are flat and extensive summits of submerged marine islands.

questions.question: Give an example of an oceanic plateau.
questions.answer: Chagos Plateau in the Indian Ocean is an example of an oceanic plateau.

questions.question: What are marine trenches?
questions.answer: Marine trenches are deep, narrow, and steep landforms on the ocean bed.

questions.question: What is the deepest trench in the world?
questions.answer: The Mariana Trench in the Pacific Ocean is the deepest trench.

questions.question: What is the depth of the Mariana Trench?
questions.answer: The Mariana Trench is approximately 11034 metres deep.

questions.question: Why are trenches geologically active?
questions.answer: Trenches have active volcanoes and are prone to earthquakes, making them geologically active.

questions.question: What causes tsunamis in coastal areas?
questions.answer: Tsunamis are caused by earthquakes and volcanic eruptions occurring on the ocean bed.

questions.question: What are marine deposits?
questions.answer: Marine deposits are materials like pebbles, clay, and soil brought by rivers and glaciers into the ocean.

questions.question: Where do marine deposits mainly occur?
questions.answer: Marine deposits mainly occur on the continental shelf.

questions.question: What are marine oozes?
questions.answer: Marine oozes are fine clay-like deposits made of soil particles and remains of marine plants and animals.

questions.question: What percentage of marine deposits are marine oozes?
questions.answer: Marine oozes make up around 30% of marine deposits.

questions.question: How are sedimentary rocks formed in the ocean?
questions.answer: Sedimentary rocks are formed by layers of sediment deposited under the pressure of seawater.

questions.question: What are anthropogenic marine deposits?
questions.answer: Anthropogenic deposits are human-made wastes like sewage, plastics, and chemicals dumped into the ocean.

questions.question: Why are human-made deposits harmful?
questions.answer: They are hazardous to marine life, the ocean environment, and can pollute the hydrosphere.

questions.question: What is Mean Sea Level?
questions.answer: Mean Sea Level is the average of the highest high tides and lowest low tides, used as a reference for measuring elevation.

questions.question: How is elevation measured in India?
questions.answer: In India, the height of sea level at Chennai is considered zero for measuring elevation.

questions.question: What is the elevation of Mount Everest?
questions.answer: Mount Everest is 8848 metres above sea level.

questions.question: What is the depth of Mariana Trench below sea level?
questions.answer: The Mariana Trench is -11034 metres below sea level.

questions.question: Why is the ocean floor considered uneven?
questions.answer: Like land, the ocean floor has varying depths and landforms such as shelves, slopes, plains, and trenches.

questions.question: What is the relief of the ocean floor?
questions.answer: The relief of the ocean floor refers to all submerged landforms and their variations in depth and shape.

questions.question: How does the ocean floor differ from one ocean to another?
questions.answer: The structure and relief of the ocean floor vary between oceans due to different geological features.

questions.question: What is the main economic importance of the continental shelf?
questions.answer: The continental shelf is rich in fishing grounds, oil, natural gas, and minerals.

questions.question: What is the lower boundary of the continental slope considered?
questions.answer: The lower boundary of the continental slope is considered the boundary of continents.

questions.question: What kind of landforms are found on abyssal plains?
questions.answer: Abyssal plains contain submerged hills, plateaus, and other flat landforms.

questions.question: Give an example of a volcanic marine island.
questions.answer: Iceland in the Atlantic Ocean is an example of a volcanic marine island.

questions.question: What is the difference between marine deeps and trenches?
questions.answer: Marine deeps are shallower, while trenches are deeper and extend over longer distances.

questions.question: Why are mid-oceanic ridges and trenches geologically active?
questions.answer: They are located at tectonic plate boundaries, leading to volcanic and seismic activity.

questions.question: What role do marine deposits play in understanding Earth’s history?
questions.answer: They help scientists study past marine life, climate, and geological changes.

questions.question: How old are the oldest deposits on the ocean floor?
questions.answer: Deposits on the ocean floor are not older than 200 million years.

questions.question: How does the age of the ocean floor compare to continental rocks?
questions.answer: The ocean floor is much younger; continental rocks can be up to 3200 million years old.

questions.question: What scientific theory was supported by the study of ocean floor rocks?
questions.answer: The study supported the theory of plate tectonics.

questions.question: What natural materials are commonly found on coastlines?
questions.answer: Materials like plants, shells, conches, and aquatic animals are commonly found.

questions.question: What human-made materials pollute coastlines?
questions.answer: Plastics, glass, chemicals, and metals are common pollutants.

questions.question: What is biodiversity in oceans compared to land?
questions.answer: Biodiversity in oceans is higher than on land.

questions.question: Why should we protect marine environments?
questions.answer: To preserve biodiversity, prevent pollution, and maintain ecological balance.

questions.question: What is the purpose of studying the ocean floor?
questions.answer: To understand Earth’s geology, locate resources, and predict natural disasters.

questions.question: How can we reduce ocean pollution?
questions.answer: By minimizing waste disposal, recycling, and promoting environmental awareness.

questions.question: Why is the continental shelf also called the submerged coastland?
questions.answer: Because it is the part of the continent that lies under shallow seawater near the coast.

questions.question: What is the typical width of a continental shelf?
questions.answer: It varies; it can be narrow along some coasts and hundreds of kilometers wide along others.

questions.question: What is the slope of the continental shelf like?
questions.answer: The slope of the continental shelf is gentle.

questions.question: Why does sunlight reach the continental shelf?
questions.answer: Because it is the shallowest part of the ocean bed, usually less than 200 meters deep.

questions.question: What type of resources can be mined from the continental shelf?
questions.answer: Mineral oil, natural gas, and various minerals can be mined from the continental shelf.

questions.question: What is the depth at which the continental slope begins?
questions.answer: The continental slope begins at about 200 meters below sea level.

questions.question: Why is the continental slope narrow?
questions.answer: It is a steep transitional zone between the continental shelf and the deep ocean floor.

questions.question: What lies at the base of the continental slope?
questions.answer: The base of the continental slope marks the beginning of the abyssal plains.

questions.question: What is the primary characteristic of abyssal plains?
questions.answer: Abyssal plains are flat and extensive areas of the deep ocean floor.

questions.question: What kind of underwater features are found on abyssal plains?
questions.answer: Hills, plateaus, and other submerged landforms are found on abyssal plains.

questions.question: How long can submerged mountain ranges be?
questions.answer: Submerged mountain ranges can be thousands of kilometers long.

questions.question: What is the main difference between marine islands and oceanic plateaus?
questions.answer: Marine islands are peaks of submerged mountains, while oceanic plateaus have flat and extensive summits.

questions.question: Give an example of an island that is a peak of a submerged mountain.
questions.answer: Andaman and Nicobar Islands are peaks of submerged mountains.

questions.question: What is the main difference between a marine deep and a trench?
questions.answer: A marine deep is shallower, while a trench is deeper and extends over a longer distance.

questions.question: Where are most marine trenches located?
questions.answer: Most marine trenches are located in the Pacific Ocean.

questions.question: Why are trenches prone to earthquakes?
questions.answer: Trenches are located at tectonic plate boundaries where plates converge, causing seismic activity.

questions.question: What are the main sources of marine deposits?
questions.answer: Rivers, glaciers, volcanic eruptions, and human activities are main sources of marine deposits.

questions.question: What are the two main types of natural marine deposits?
questions.answer: The two main types are terrigenous deposits (from land) and biogenous deposits (from marine life).

questions.question: What is volcanic ash considered in marine deposits?
questions.answer: Volcanic ash is considered a part of marine deposits from volcanic eruptions.

questions.question: What are the remains of marine plants and animals called in marine deposits?
questions.answer: They are called marine oozes when mixed with fine particles.

questions.question: What is the significance of marine oozes?
questions.answer: They help in understanding past marine life and the availability of minerals.

questions.question: How do sedimentary rocks form in the ocean?
questions.answer: They form from layers of sediment compressed under the weight of seawater over time.

questions.question: What human activities contribute to ocean pollution?
questions.answer: Dumping sewage, solid waste, radioactive materials, chemicals, and plastics into the ocean.

questions.question: What is the main environmental impact of ocean pollution?
questions.answer: It harms marine life, disrupts ecosystems, and pollutes the hydrosphere.

questions.question: How is mean sea level calculated?
questions.answer: It is the average of the highest high tides and the lowest low tides over a long period.

questions.question: Why is Chennai’s sea level used as a reference in India?
questions.answer: For survey purposes, the sea level at Chennai is considered the standard zero point in India.

questions.question: What does a negative depth value indicate?
questions.answer: A negative depth value indicates a location below sea level, such as a trench.

questions.question: What does a positive elevation value indicate?
questions.answer: A positive elevation value indicates a location above sea level, such as a mountain.

questions.question: What is the main reason for the uneven ocean floor?
questions.answer: Tectonic activity, volcanic eruptions, and erosion create variations in the ocean floor.

questions.question: What is the relief of the ocean floor determined by?
questions.answer: It is determined by the depth and shape of submerged landforms.

questions.question: Why is the continental shelf important for oil exploration?
questions.answer: It contains reserves of mineral oil and natural gas, such as Mumbai High.

questions.question: What is the main use of abyssal plains in marine research?
questions.answer: Abyssal plains are studied to understand deep-sea geology and marine ecosystems.

questions.question: What is the main difference between the continental shelf and the continental slope?
questions.answer: The shelf is shallow and gentle, while the slope is steep and marks the drop to the deep ocean.

questions.question: What are submarine plateaus?
questions.answer: Submarine plateaus are flat-topped elevations on the ocean floor, also called oceanic plateaus.

questions.question: Give an example of a submarine plateau.
questions.answer: Chagos Plateau in the Indian Ocean is a submarine plateau.

questions.question: What are mid-oceanic ridges?
questions.answer: Mid-oceanic ridges are underwater mountain ranges formed by tectonic activity.

questions.question: Why are mid-oceanic ridges geologically active?
questions.answer: They are sites of seafloor spreading, volcanic activity, and earthquakes.

questions.question: What is the main hazard of volcanic eruptions on the ocean floor?
questions.answer: They can cause tsunamis and disrupt marine ecosystems.

questions.question: What is the role of glaciers in marine deposition?
questions.answer: Glaciers carry rocks, soil, and sediments into the ocean when they melt.

questions.question: What are the main components of marine sediments?
questions.answer: Clay, silt, sand, volcanic ash, and remains of marine organisms.

questions.question: What is the economic importance of marine minerals?
questions.answer: Marine minerals are used in industries, construction, and technology.

questions.question: How do human activities affect marine biodiversity?
questions.answer: Pollution, overfishing, and habitat destruction reduce marine biodiversity.

questions.question: What is the main goal of deep-sea research?
questions.answer: To explore unknown ecosystems, discover resources, and understand Earth’s history.

questions.question: Why are marine trenches important for geological studies?
questions.answer: They provide insights into plate tectonics, subduction zones, and deep-sea processes.

questions.question: What is the significance of the age of ocean floor rocks?
questions.answer: It supports the theory of plate tectonics and helps reconstruct Earth’s geological history.

questions.question: How can we protect marine environments from pollution?
questions.answer: By reducing waste, enforcing laws, and promoting sustainable practices.

questions.question: What is the main difference between natural and anthropogenic deposits?
questions.answer: Natural deposits come from natural processes, while anthropogenic deposits come from human activities.

questions.question: Why is the continental shelf ideal for marine life?
questions.answer: Sunlight, nutrients, and shallow waters support abundant marine life.

questions.question: What is the main threat to the continental shelf ecosystem?
questions.answer: Pollution, overfishing, and habitat destruction are major threats.

questions.question: What is the future of ocean floor exploration?
questions.answer: Advanced technology will enable deeper exploration, resource discovery, and environmental protection.
